metadata.synopsis: A young man, Vince Everett (Elvis Presley), is convicted of manslaughter after being drawn into a bar fight while trying to defend a woman. In prison, Everett finds salvation when his cellmate, a country singer named Hunk Houghton (Mickey Shaughnessy), hears him sing and pegs him as a future star. Once released, Everett gets a job in a night club and meets Peggy Van Alden (Judy Tyler), a young woman who works for a record company and who, like Houghton, also sees talent in Everett.

reviews: Jailhouse Rock (1957) is a prison-related, rags-to-riches musical-drama (and biopic parable of a predictable downfall and recovery) from director Richard Thorpe. It was the most influential black-and-white rock musical...
'50s Elvis film still charms; some mild violence, smoking.

Embora Presley fosse um pssimo ator, seu carisma e sua intensidade nos nmeros musicais transformam este em seu melhor filme, j que, alm de evitar as frmulas que viriam a dominar seus longas, ele estabelece uma tima qumica com Tyler.
Even if the plot is thin, the characterizations are solid, and the music is some of Elvis's best.
Elvis delivered his definitive screen appearance in this budget-minded black and white production, a dark reflection of the Loving You rise to fame.

Just a notch above the average Elvis vehicle (which is not very high), this early b/w effort (Elvis' third feature) suffers from a silly prison yarn but is ultimately saved by the rendition of some good rocking tuners like the title song.
An early, lively Elvis musical, aesthetically light years from the tacky one-offs, such as Spinout that followed. The title number... well, it rocks.
singing carries the day, just as we'd expect in an Elvis movie
